title: 109_s1251
content: The Act titled "Rocky Flats Environmental Technology Site Act of 2005" includes definitions for clarity. The Act "Rocky Flats Environmental Technology Site Act of 2005" defines "covenant not to sue" as a waiver of legal action under environmental laws and "essential mineral right" as a mineral necessary for transitioning Rocky Flats to a National Wildlife Refuge. The draft memorandum of understanding between the Department of the Interior and the Department of Energy defines terms like fair market value, natural resource damage liability, and Rocky Flats. The Rocky Flats Environmental Technology Site in Colorado is managed by the Department of Energy. The term "Secretary" refers to the Secretary of Energy, and "Trustees" are Federal and State officials designated under a specific act. SEC. 3. ROCKY FLATS ENVIRONMENTAL TECHNOLOGY SITE. The Secretary will use funds to purchase essential mineral rights at Rocky Flats within a year of the Act's enactment. Conditions include the owner being willing, fair market value purchase, and a natural resources damage settlement. The Secretary will purchase essential mineral rights at Rocky Flats using funds available under subsection (b) and settle any natural resource damage claims. If an owner refuses to sell at fair market value, the Secretary has the authority to satisfy the claim. The Secretary can satisfy natural resource damage liability by paying the Trustees fair market value for essential mineral rights owned by an unwilling seller. This settles claims under the Comprehensive Environmental Response, Compensation, and Liability Act. Any claim for damage to a natural resource can be satisfied by the Secretary purchasing essential mineral rights or making a payment to the Trustees. The Secretary can settle natural resource damage liability by paying the Trustees fair market value for essential mineral rights. This purchase is exempt from the National Environmental Policy Act. $10,000,000 is authorized for fiscal year 2006.
